vega.graph
Class AbstractGraph<V extends Vertex<V,E>,E extends Edge>

java.lang.Object
  vega.graph.AbstractGraph<V,E>
All Implemented Interfaces:
Graph<V,E>
Direct Known Subclasses:
AbstractNetwork, AbstractTree
public class AbstractGraph<V extends Vertex<V,E>,E extends Edge>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Graph<V,E>

The graph class is built off the mathematical structure of the same name. As stated on wikipedia: "In mathematics and computer science, a graph is the basic object of study in graph theory. Informally speaking, a graph is a set of objects called points, nodes, or vertices connected by links called lines or edges. In a proper graph, which is by default undirected, a line from point A to point B is considered to be the same thing as a line from point B to point A. In a digraph, short for directed graph, the two directions are counted as being distinct arcs or directed edges. Typically, a graph is depicted in diagrammatic form as a set of dots (for the points, vertices, or nodes), joined by curves (for the lines or edges)."

Author:
w_jossey

Constructor Detail

AbstractGraph

public AbstractGraph(int vertexSize,
                     boolean isDigraph)
The constructor method for the Graph class. Takes in a pre-set vertex and a boolean setting to distinguish if it is a directed-graph or undirected-graph.

Parameters:
vertexSize - the number of vertices in the graph
digraph - a directed graph if true, undirected if false

AbstractGraph

public AbstractGraph(int vertexSize,
                     int edgeSize,
                     boolean digraph)
Constructor class when we don't have a complete graph. Has yet to be implemented yet. The problem generating random graphs is mostly due to the question of whether or not the graph is strongly connected or not.

Parameters:
vertexSize - the number of vertices in the graph
edgeSize - the number of edges in the graph
digraph - a directed graph if true, undirected if false

generateEdges

private void generateEdges()
This method merely loops through the vertexArray array that has been already created. It takes the current vertex, saves it as tempVertex, and adds edges to and from this vertex. By guaranteeing that there is always a flow in and out of the vertex, we are guaranteed a strongly connected graph.

addVertex

public void addVertex(V v)
Adds a vertex to the vertex array. Internal method only.

Specified by:
addVertex in interface Graph<V extends Vertex<V,E>,E extends Edge>
Parameters:
v - Vertex to add

computeDistances

private void computeDistances()
This algorithm goes through and produces all of the edge weights between the vertices if we're working with a complete graph. This is particularly useful in situations such as TSP where we are dealing with some complete Graph and want it to auto-generate the edges for us
